chapter.title: Troubleshooting and Support
chapter.para: Find solutions for the most common pitfalls and technical details on how to create a support request for &productname; here.

sect1.title: FAQ
sect1.para: If your problem is not mentioned here, checking the log files on either the &admserv; or the &ostack; nodes may help. A list of log files is available at .

question.para: What to do if the initial &inst_crow; on the &admserv; fails?

answer.para: Check the installation routine's log file at /var/log/crowbar/install.log for error messages.

question.para: What to do if the initial &inst_crow; on the &admserv; fails while deploying the IPMI/BMC network?

answer.para: As of &productname; 8, it is assumed that each machine can be accessed directly via IPMI/BMC. However, this is not the case on certain blade hardware, where several nodes are accessed via a common adapter. Such a hardware setup causes an error on deploying the IPMI/BMC network. You need to disable the IPMI deployment running the following command:
Re-run the &inst_crow; after having disabled the IPMI deployment.

question.para: Why am I not able to reach the &admserv; from outside the admin network via the bastion network?

answer.para: If route -n shows no gateway for the bastion network, check the value of the following entries in /etc/crowbar/network.json: "router_pref": and "router_pref":. Make sure the value for the bastion network's "router_pref": is set to a lower value than "router_pref": for the admin network.

If the router preference is set correctly, route -n shows a gateway for the bastion network. In case the &admserv; is still not accessible via its admin network address (for example, 192.168.124.10), you need to disable route verification (rp_filter). Do so by running the following command on the &admserv;:
If this setting solves the problem, make it permanent by editing /etc/sysctl.conf and setting the value for net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter to 0.

question.para: Can I change the host name of the &admserv;?

answer.para: No, after you have run the &inst_crow; you cannot change the host name. Services like &crow;, &chef;, and the RabbitMQ will fail after changing the host name.

question.para: What to do when browsing the &chef; Web UI gives a Tampered with cookie error?

answer.para: You probably have an old cookie in your browser from a previous &chef; installation on the same IP address. Remove the cookie named _chef_server_session_id and try again.

question.para: How to make custom software repositories from an external server (for example a remote SMT or SUSE Manager server) available for the nodes?

answer.para: Custom repositories need to be added using the &yast; Crowbar module:

step.para: Start the &yast; Crowbar module and switch to the Repositories tab: &yast; Miscellaneous Crowbar Repositories.
Choose Add Repositories
Enter the following data:

listitem.para: A unique name to identify the repository.
Link or path to the repository.
Access errors to a repository are silently ignored by default. To ensure that you get notified of these errors, set the Ask On Error flag.
Currently only repositories for SLE 12 SP2 on the x86_64 architecture are supported. Make sure to select both options.

step.para: Save your settings selecting OK.

question.para: How can I log in to a node as &rootuser;?

answer.para: By default you cannot directly log in to a node as &rootuser;, because the nodes were set up without a &rootuser; password. You can only log in via SSH from the &admserv;. You should be able to log in to a node with ssh root@NAME where NAME is the name (alias) of the node.

If name resolution does not work, go to the &crow; Web interface and open the Node Dashboard. Click the name of the node and look for its admin (eth0) IP Address. Log in to that IP address via SSH as user &rootuser;.

question.para: What to do if a node refuses to boot or boots into a previous installation?

answer.para: Make sure to change the boot order in the BIOS of the node, so that the first boot option is to boot from the network/boot using PXE.

question.para: What to do if a node hangs during hardware discovery after the very first boot using PXE into the SLEShammer image?

answer.para: The &rootuser; login is enabled at a very early state in discovery mode, so chances are high that you can log in for debugging purposes as described in . This can either be done by setting the password via the Kernel command line as explained in , or by creating a hook as explained below:

answer.para: Kernel Parameters for the SLEShammer Discovery Image can be provided via the Provisioner &barcl;. The following example shows how to set a &rootuser; password:

question.para: What to do when a deployed node fails to boot using PXE with the following error message: Could not find kernel image: ../suse-12.2/install/boot/x86_64/loader/linux?

answer.para: The installation repository on the &admserv; at /srv/tftpboot/suse-12.3/install has not been set up correctly to contain the &cloudos; installation media. Review the instructions at .

question.para: Why does my deployed node hang at Unpacking initramfs during boot when using PXE?

answer.para: The node probably does not have enough RAM. You need at least 4 GB RAM for the deployment process to work.

answer.para: Be patient—the &ay; script may take a while to finish. If it really hangs, log in to the node as &rootuser; (see for details). Check for error messages at the end of /var/log/crowbar/crowbar_join/chef.log. Fix the errors and restart the &ay; script by running the following command:

In cases where the initial --setup wasn't able to complete successfully, you can rerun that once after the previous issue is solved.
If that does not help or if the log does not provide useful information, proceed as follows:

Check the output of the command for failures and error messages and try to fix the cause of these messages.

answer.para: If the node is in a state where login in from the &admserv; is not possible, you need to create a &rootuser; password for it as described in . Now re-install the node by going to the node on the &crow; Web interface and clicking Reinstall. After having been re-installed, the node will hang again, but now you can log in and check the log files to find the cause.

question.para: Where to find more information when applying a &barcl; proposal fails?

answer.para: Check the &chef; client log files on the &admserv; located at /var/log/crowbar/chef-client/d*.log. Further information is available from the &chef; client log files located on the node(s) affected by the proposal (/var/log/chef/client.log), and from the log files of the service that failed to be deployed. Additional information may be gained from the &crow; Web UI log files on the &admserv;. For a list of log file locations refer to .

question.para: How to Prevent the &admserv; from Installing the &ostack; Nodes (Disable PXE and DNS Services)?

answer.para: By default, the &ostack; nodes are installed by booting a discovery image from the &admserv; using PXE. They are allocated and then boot via PXE into an automatic installation (see for details). To install the &ostack; nodes manually or with a custom provisioning tool, you need to disable the PXE boot service and the DNS service on the &admserv;.
As a consequence you also need to provide an external DNS server. Such a server needs to comply with the following requirements:

listitem.para: It needs to handle all domain-to-IP requests for &cloud;.
It needs to handle all IP-to-domain requests for &cloud;.
It needs to forward unknown requests to other DNS servers.

question.para: I have installed a new hard disk on a node that was already deployed. Why is it ignored by &crow;?

answer.para: When adding a new hard disk to a node that has already been deployed, it can take up to 15 minutes before the new disk is detected.

question.para: How to install additional packages (for example a driver) when nodes are deployed?

answer.para: &productname; offers the possibility to install additional packages that are not part of the default scope of packages installed on the &ostack; nodes. This is for example required if your hardware is only supported by a third party driver. It is also useful if your setup requires to install additional tools that would otherwise need to be installed manually.

Prerequisite for using this feature is that the packages are available in a repository known on the &admserv;. Refer to for details, if the packages you want to install are not part of the repositories already configured.
To add packages for installation on node deployment, proceed as follows:

sect1.title: Support
sect1.para:
2012-09-07 - fs: Do we have some official text on cloud and support we could use here?
Before contacting support to help you with a problem on &cloud;, it is strongly recommended that you gather as much information about your system and the problem as possible. For this purpose, &productname; ships with a tool called supportconfig. It gathers system information such as the current kernel version being used, the hardware, RPM database, partitions, and other items. supportconfig also collects the most important log files, making it easier for the supporters to identify and solve your problem.

It is recommended to always run supportconfig on the &admserv; and on the &contrnode;(s). If a &compnode; or a &stornode; is part of the problem, run supportconfig on the affected node as well. For details on how to run supportconfig, see .
